definition:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be topological spaces. A function $f\colon X\to Y$ is
said to be *coercive* if for every compact set $J\subset Y$ there exists
a compact set $K\subset X$ such that
$$F(X\setminus K) \subset Y\setminus J.$$

The general definition given above has a clear sense when specialized to
the Euclidean spaces, as shown in the following result.

A function $f\colon {\mathbb R}^n \to {\mathbb R}^m$ is coercive if and
only if $$\lim_{|x|\to +\infty} |f(x)| = +\infty.$$
